I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) will support improved water planning, 
management, and development in Indonesia.1 The government requested the TA in a dialogue 
between  the  National  Development  Planning  Agency  (BAPPENAS),  the  Ministry  of  Public 
Works, and Asian Development Bank (ADB). Concept clearance for the TA was approved on 8 
April 2013. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Development agenda. The well-being of the Indonesian people depends heavily on 
water. As Indonesia grows, enjoying annual economic expansion that averaged 5.7% in 2005–
2010 and accelerated to 6.5% in 2011, water challenges intensify and jeopardize sustained 
development. To guide its economic development, Indonesia prepared the Acceleration and 
Expansion of Indonesia Economic Development, 2011–2025 (MP3EI) that is based on three 
pillars—(i)  developing  the  economic  potential  of  six  regional  corridors;2 (ii)  strengthening 
national connectivity locally and internationally; and (iii) strengthening human resource capacity, 
science, and technology. The MP3EI recognizes food security and improved water and energy 
policies as prerequisites for its implementation. In 2014, Indonesia will update its National 
Medium-Term  Development  Plan  (RPJMN),  2015–2019,  which  guides  planning  within  and 
across sectors. Together, the RPJMN and the MP3EI provide the economic and development 
planning  framework  for  Indonesia,  within  which  the  government  wants  to  prioritize  water 
concerns to sustain economic growth. 
 
3.  The  government’s  development  agenda  requires  assistance  to  analyze  the  water 
concerns and priorities of the MP3EI. This assistance should include support for country water 
assessment  (CWA)  that  will  help  provide  the  analytical  foundation  for  water  planning, 
management, and development, including investment to further economic development. The 
MP3EI can guide the priorities to be addressed under the CWA, and detailed water sector plans 
can support the economic development agendas of the regional corridors under the MP3EI. The 
CWA  can  advance  water  reform  across  Indonesia  while  providing  guidance  for  planning, 
management, policy, and investment in the MP3EI economic corridors. Analysis for the CWA 
and its associated regional plans can support RPJMN development and ensure synergy with the 
MP3EI. The CWA will also provide guidance to help address the many challenges facing 
effective water resources management (WRM) and reliable water service delivery in Indonesia.3 
 
4.  Water  supply  and  sanitation  challenges.  Indonesia’s  economic  growth  spurs 
urbanization, with the percentage of Indonesians living in urban areas expected to increase from 
53% in 2010 to 65% by 2025. Government decentralization has tasked local governments with 
managing  water  supply  agencies  (PDAMs),  70%  of  which  are  heavily  indebted  and  have 
extremely high nonrevenue water losses, some exceeding 50%. Rates of access to water 
supply and sanitation (WSS) have been declining, with piped water supply reaching only about 
31% of urban residents and 12% of rural residents. PDAMs supply water to only 18% of all 
Indonesians.  Sewage  treatment  coverage  is  very  low,  serving  less  than  1%  of  the  urban 
population. 
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 22 July 2013. A fact-finding 
mission  from  20  February  to  9  April  2013  (intermittent)  confirmed  the  TA’s  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants. 
2  The corridors include Sumatra, Java, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, Bali–Nusa Tenggara, and Papua–Kepulauan Maluku. 
3  The challenges are highlighted in ADB sector assessments, strategies, and road maps for the sectors (i) water 
supply and sanitation and (ii) agriculture, environment, and natural resources.

2  
5.  Water resources challenges. Significant WRM challenges exist. Sediment caused by 
watershed degradation damages water infrastructure and raises water treatment costs. On Java 
alone from 2003 to 2009, flooding annually took an average of 140 lives, 20,000 homes, and 
100,000 hectares (ha) of crops. Both land-use changes and excessive groundwater extraction 
that causes land subsidence have worsened flooding, which is now an annual occurrence 
throughout much of Indonesia. It is estimated that 70% of groundwater sources and 75% of 
rivers are polluted, limiting water resource sustainability and posing risks to public health. In 
2005,  5.2  million  ha  of  the  total  irrigated  area  of  6.7  million  ha,  or  78%,  was  served  by 
infrastructure considered in good condition. As the irrigated area expanded to 7.2 million ha in 
2010, the area in good condition shrank to only 3.5 million ha, or 48%. Climate change will 
further challenge Indonesia’s WRM as water scarcity worsens in some areas, extreme weather 
events become more frequent, and rainfall patterns become less favorable for agriculture. 
 
6.  Institutional and management challenges. Many of the same problems affect both 
WSS and WRM as water challenges become increasingly interdependent and confront policy 
makers  with  trade-offs.  Institutional  arrangements  and  fiscal  options  for  water  operations, 
maintenance, and management need to be strengthened. The regulatory framework for WSS is 
inadequate to support sector development. WSS operations generally fail to recover operation 
and maintenance costs, and farmers pay no irrigation service fees. Technical and administrative 
capacity constraints hamper effective planning, management, and development as Indonesia’s 
decentralized  government  structure  heightens  capacity  challenges.  District,  provincial,  and 
central government roles and fund flows need to be clearer and better coordinated, and different 
agencies’ program, policy, and management responsibilities harmonized. Although economic 
growth has been robust, planning and infrastructure investment have been inadequate to meet 
rising water sector demands. Importantly, the private sector has been underutilized and should 
play a larger role not only for WSS but increasingly for WRM. 
 
7.  Improved WRM is vital for WSS and economic growth. Increased bulk water supply is 
needed to (i) support WSS expansion as PDAMs restructure; (ii) meet growing municipal, 
industrial, and agricultural service demand; and (iii) ease overreliance on groundwater. An 
urgent  concern  is  to  enhance  the  policy  framework  and  capacity  toward  facilitating  the 
development  of  new  bulk  water  sources  and  improving  water  allocation  among  competing 
demands.  The  water–food–energy  nexus  provides  an  important  paradigm  to  assess  the 
economic trade-offs in sound water policy and planning decisions. Agriculture uses 88% of the 
developed water supply in Indonesia, and food security is a growing government priority. In 
2011, the government called for rice production to increase by 10 million tons, or by 15%, to 
address food  insecurity,4 and the  MP3EI  prioritizes  (i)  security  in  both  the  production  and 
consumption of food and (ii) developing new food-production areas, in particular outside of Java. 
Energy demand is increasing at twice the rate of GDP growth, and water is critical to develop 
hydropower and service thermal energy production, which is expanding rapidly. Energy typically 
comprises 50% of the cost of urban water supply. The water–food–energy nexus provides an 
informed and transparent framework for determining and resolving trade-offs to meet rising 
demand while addressing sustainability. This type of analysis is needed to support the CWA and 
ensure sound water planning that will achieve the goals of Indonesia’s MP3EI and the next 
RPJMN. 
 
8.  Ongoing ADB activities. ADB has a well-developed and growing water program, with 
both sovereign and private sector operations. The TA project Water Supply and Sanitation 
                                                
4  Presidential Decree 5/2011, Security in National Rice Production in Facing Extreme Climate Condition. Jakarta.

3
Sector Development is helping BAPPENAS to assess WSS and develop a policy road map.5 
ADB supports sanitation with the ongoing Metropolitan Sanitation Management and Health 
Project 6  and  a  new  sanitation  project  under  preparation. 7  The  TA  project  Institutional 
Strengthening for the Water Resources Sector is reviewing role-sharing by national, provincial, 
and district governments for irrigation and river basin management to improve coordination.8 
The Directorate General of Water Resources under the Ministry of Public Works is adopting 
irrigation reforms based on experience from the Participatory Irrigation Sector Project.9 The 
Integrated  Citarum  Water  Resources  Management  Investment  Program  provides 
comprehensive support to the government to advance river basin planning and management 
through a 15-year commitment.10 Capacity building is an important part of ADB’s program, and 
ADB TA for Supporting Water Operators’ Partnerships facilitates water practitioner exchange to 
develop  PDAM  capacity.11 ADB’s  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  has  invested  in 
Jakarta’s water supply concessionaires and has other water-related proposals pending.12 ADB 
directly  supports  the  MP3EI  through  3-year  policy-based  lending  for  the  Inclusive  Growth 
through Improved Connectivity Program.13 ADB has a robust and growing water program but 
would  benefit  from  a  more  coordinated  and  integrated  approach  across  subsectors  and 
assistance modalities. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact will be improved water planning and investment. The outcome will be an 
updated strategic framework for water planning, management, and development. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: country water assessment and strategic planning. Output 1 will have 
three activities. The primary activity will be to develop a CWA that aligns with the government’s 
MP3EI to integrate water priorities more fully into development planning. The priorities of ADB's 
Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020 will also guide CWA development.14 The approach will use

4  
existing water sector information and analysis, where available, from the government, ADB, and 
other development partners and integrate them with the CWA’s analytical framework. The CWA 
will address national water policy issues and include detailed water sector plans to support the 
specific  MP3EI  economic  development  strategies  for  the  Java  and  the  Sumatra  regional 
corridors  (which  generate  over  80%  of  Indonesia’s  GDP)  and  up  to  two  other  regional 
corridors.15 The CWA will synthesize sector and subsector issues using a holistic approach to 
evaluate trade-offs and issues across sectors. It will include analysis of the water–food–energy 
nexus to develop regional corridor water sector plans based on the MP3EI. The regional water 
plans for the economic corridors will include recommendations for investment, management, 
and  institutional  and  policy  reform  to  support  specific  regional  growth  strategies.  Local 
governments will be involved in developing the regional water sector plans related to the MP3EI 
to ensure alignment with local initiatives. 
 
11.  The second activity responds to the government’s request for assistance to develop 
water-related sections of the new RPJMN. The CWA will provide the analytical basis, and the 
TA  will  produce  relevant  sections  of  the  RPJMN  and  support  background  studies  and 
presentations. For both the CWA and RPJMN, the TA will support extensive consultations with 
national and local governments, development partners, civil society, the private sector, and 
other stakeholders. The third activity will prepare an ADB water operational plan for 2014–2020 
for Indonesia, which will guide ADB water loans and grants program, ensuring that it aligns with 
the  government’s  priorities  and  the  ADB  Water  Operational  Plan.  The  Indonesia  water 
operational plan will integrate WSS and WRM perspectives and address interdependent issues 
that  are  becoming  increasingly  urgent  and  should  be  reflected  under  an  integrated  ADB 
approach. The  plan  will  address both  sovereign  and  nonsovereign  programs  and facilitate 
dialogue and the government’s engagement with ADB’s long-term water investment program. 
 
12.  Output 2: capacity development and knowledge transfer. An important priority to 
improve  water  planning,  management,  and  development  is  strengthened  capacity  and 
knowledge transfer. The main activity under output 2 will be Indonesia Water Learning Week 
(WLW), which will accompany CWA development. WLW will be an international event to bring 
together  senior  government  policy  makers,  development  partners,  civil  society,  the  private 
sector, and other stakeholders. It will be an opportunity to (i) develop a common perspective on 
water sector challenges; (ii) conduct policy dialogue on the government’s priorities to improve 
water sector planning, management and development; (iii) validate the draft CWA; and (iv) 
transfer knowledge on key issues. Using national and international resource persons, WLW will 
raise awareness and develop commitment to support the CWA's reform recommendations. ADB 
has  discussed  WLW  with  development  partners,  which  have  indicated  their  support  and 
intended participation. 
 
13.  The second activity under output 2 will develop capacity and transfer knowledge through 
existing training programs and domestic and international seminars for government counterparts 
on water issues addressed through the CWA. This output may include specialized  in situ 
training and the development of training materials for needs identified in consultation with the 
government. The output will develop at least one knowledge product related to the CWA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,600,000, of which $1,500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Netherlands  Trust  Fund  under  the  Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility  and 
                                                
15 The additional regional corridors that will have water sector plans prepared under the TA will be selected in 
consultation with the government during the TA inception mission.

5
administered by ADB. The Government of Indonesia will provide support in the form of office 
accommodation, counterpart staff, a national steering committee, and a technical working group. 
The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The  Directorate  of  Water  Resources  and  Irrigation  under  BAPPENAS  will  be  the 
executing agency, and the Ministry of Public Works will be the implementing agency. A national 
steering committee chaired by BAPPENAS will be established to guide policy for the CWA and 
WLW. It will include the Ministry of Public Works, the Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs, 
and other ministries.16 BAPPENAS will manage inputs to the RPJMN, which is under its purview, 
and be responsible for coordinating TA outputs. The TA will establish, in addition to the national 
steering committee, a technical working group of line agencies and local government for the 
CWA and WLW. BAPPENAS has substantial experience implementing ADB TAs. 
 
16.  The  TA  will  require  117  person-months  of  consulting  services  (26  person-months 
international and 91 person-months national) over an implementation period of 16 months 
starting in September 2013, with an additional 3 months for TA closing. A firm will be recruited 
for the CWA and WLW using (i) quality- and cost-based selection at a ratio of 90:10 and (ii) a 
simplified technical proposal. Additional individual consultants may be recruited as needed, and 
lump  sum  contracts  for  discrete  outputs  may  be  used.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time). The terms of reference are in Appendix 3. Procurement will be in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time), and the procured equipment will 
be turned over to the government upon TA completion. TA funds will support workshops, 
seminars, and other capacity development, as well as the travel of ADB staff to participate in 
related  TA  events.  All  disbursements  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
17.  The TA is also designed to provide a platform for discussion and advisory services for 
ADB’s water operations. ADB will meet frequently with government officials to discuss TA 
progress and output application. TA outputs and lessons will be disseminated through (i) the 
WLW;  (ii)  workshops  and  conferences  in  Indonesia  and  abroad;  (iii)  consultation  with 
development partners, the private sector, and civil society; (iv) ADB's water community of 
practice; and (v) at least one new knowledge product. Workshops will vet outputs from the 
CWAs and its water sector plans for selected economic corridors under the MP3EI. ADB and, 
through the national steering committee and BAPPENAS, the government will monitor and 
evaluate the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,500,000  to  the 
Government of Indonesia to be financed on a grant basis by the Netherlands Trust Fund under 
the  Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility  for  Improving Water  Planning,  Management,  and 
Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
16 The Ministry of Public Works comprises the Directorate General of Water Resources and the Directorate for 
Human Settlements, which are responsible for WSS. The Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs is responsible 
for the MP3EI. Other ministries—such as environment, forestry, agriculture, and health—and local governments 
will likely participate on the national steering committee, as will be confirmed during the TA inception mission.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS1 
 
1.  Water sector specialists—team leader and deputy team leader (9 person-months 
international and 13 person-months national). The specialists will do the following: 
(i)  Coordinate and ensure the quality of all outputs, including the country water 
assessment  (CWA),  inputs  to  the  National  Medium-Term  Development  Plan 
(RPJMN), and the ADB water operational plan for Indonesia, 2014–2020. 
(ii)  Act as focal points and coordinate with the government, development partners, 
civil society, the private sector, and other stakeholders on all aspects of the TA. 
(iii)  Work with BAPPENAS, other government agencies, and TA team members to 
develop the CWA in line with the government’s Masterplan for Acceleration and 
Expansion  of  Indonesia  Economic  Development,  2011–2025  (MP3EI),  select 
economic development corridors, confirm the government’s CWA priorities, and 
finalize  with  the  government  its  terms  of  reference  in  the  framework  of  the 
MP3EI.2 
(iv)  The deputy team leader will, with other national specialists, compile and review 
relevant water laws, policies, regulations, and other strategic documents for use 
in the CWA and Water Learning Week (WLW). For water studies specific to the 
MP3EI corridors, the document review should include those of local governments. 
(v)  Working with the government, develop a consultation plan for the CWA, the 
regional water studies to support the MP3EI’s corridor economic plans, and other 
TA outputs.  
(vi)  Assess the role of the private sector and make recommendations for the CWA 
and the water plans regarding the selected economic corridors under the MP3EI. 
(vii)  Prepare  detailed  water  sector  plans  with  investment,  financing,  policy,  and 
management reform recommendations for selected MP3EI economic corridors; 
ensure that the plans are detailed enough to implement; and disaggregate roles, 
responsibilities,  and  financing  horizontally  across  water-related  agencies  and 
vertically across national, provincial, and district governments.  
(viii)  Coordinate with ADB staff and the government to prepare terms of reference for 
the  ADB  water  operational  plan  for  Indonesia  and  execute  it,  including 
recommendations for more effective engagement and investment with Indonesia. 
(ix)  Provide technical content for the WLW and review technical inputs. 
(x)  Lead the identification of needs for capacity development and knowledge transfer 
and  supervise  the  development  of  training  materials  and  courses  and  the 
selection of relevant capacity and knowledge events for counterpart participation. 
(xi)  In consultation with the government and ADB, select the theme of knowledge 
product(s) and direct their development with the TA team.  
(xii)  Execute other tasks as needed for the successful implementation of the TA. 
 
2.  Economists  (6  person-months  international  and  7  person-months  national).  The 
economists will 
(i)  lead the development of the framework and terms of reference of the CWA to 
support the government’s MP3IE, in consultation with the government and other 
stakeholders; 
(ii)  highlight, based on sector analysis under the MP3EI, sector performance, priority 
development constraints, government plans and strategy, past ADB support and

2  ADB has already developed generic terms of reference for the CWA, but they will be reviewed, amended, and 
confirmed during the inception mission.

Appendix 3  11 
experience,  other  development  partner  support,  and  ADB’s  future  support 
strategy; 
(iii)  identify quantitative  analytical  methods  and  develop  modeling  as  possible  to 
further economic analysis supporting the CWA and the detailed water sector 
plans for selected economic corridors of the MP3EI; 
(iv)  evaluate in the context of the CWA and MP3EI investment plans and planning at 
the national, provincial, and district level; 
(v)  recommend economic policy, institutional, management, and investment reforms 
along with development strategies in the context of CWA as a whole and for 
selected economic development corridors under the MP3EI; 
(vi)  assess the role of the private sector for the CWA and water sector plans for 
selected economic corridors under the MP3EI and make recommendations; 
(vii)  provide guidance and supporting materials for the economic analysis of the water 
sector to help BAPPENAS prepare the new RPJMN; 
(viii)  support the preparation of the ADB water operational plan for Indonesia with 
recommendations on sector work and related investments under the MP3EI; and 
(ix)  support the preparation of the WLW with regard to highlighting key economic 
issues to be included in the subsector programs. 
 
3.  Water–food–energy nexus specialists (3 person-months international and 5 person-
months national). The specialists will 
(i)  collect and review regulatory and policy framework and strategy documents that 
address water allocation as relevant to energy and agricultural development; 
(ii)  develop,  in  cooperation  with  the  TA  team,  an  assessment  methodology  to 
evaluate the water–food–energy nexus in Indonesia (likely to be done at the 
basin scale) and apply the methodology in the CWA for the water sector plans 
supporting the selected economic corridors under the MP3EI; 
(iii)  analyze  the  water  balance  in  selected  economic  corridors,  review  planned 
investments and the MP3EI economic development strategy, and develop water 
demand projections with the TA team for food (irrigation) and energy (thermal, 
hydropower, and energy use) in the context of the water–food–energy nexus;  
(iv)  project outcomes of development scenarios in the corridors of the MP3EI and 
assess trade-offs between food and energy and other competing water uses; 
(v)  develop policy, institutional, management, and investment recommendations and 
reforms to optimize options with regard to the water–food–energy nexus for the 
CWA and the selected economic corridors under the MP3EI;  
(vi)  select, in cooperation the government, one representative basin to demonstrate 
the methodology for assessing the water–food–energy nexus that can be used at 
the basin level for water resources planning and management; 
(vii)  support the preparation of sections of the new RPJMN along with background 
papers derived from the analysis for the CWA; 
(viii)  contribute to the ADB water operational plan for Indonesia; and 
(ix)  consult with the government, development partners, the private sector, and civil 
society to develop the water–food–energy nexus. 
 
4.  Water supply and sanitation specialist (5 person-months national). The specialist will 
(i)  collect and review the policy and regulatory documents, strategies, and other 
materials relevant to WSS for the CWA, particularly on local water utilities and 
their role and performance, as well as other water supply issues;

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(ii)  prepare, in cooperation with the government and TA economists, a framework for 
assessing WSS needs for development scenarios in selected economic corridors 
and associated water sector plans related to the MP3EI; 
(iii)  develop policy, institutional, management, and investment recommendations and 
reforms with regard to the WSS for the CWA and each of the economic corridors 
under the MP3EI; 
(iv)  prepare WSS sections of the new RPJMN, along with analytical background 
papers derived from the analysis for the CWA; 
(v)  assess and make recommendations regarding the role of the private sector for 
the CWA and water plans for the economic corridors under the MP3EI; 
(vi)  develop sections of the ADB water operational plan for Indonesia with a focus on 
private sector engagement for the WSS; 
(vii)  support the development of the WSS program for WLW; and 
(viii)  consult with the government, development partners, the private sector, and civil 
society to support TA WSS activities. 
 
5.  Water  quality  specialists  (2  person-months  international  and  5  person-months 
national). The specialists will 
(i)  collect  and  review  policy  and  regulatory  documents,  strategies,  and  other 
materials relevant to water quality improvement and the environment for the 
CWA; 
(ii)  prepare, in cooperation with the government and the TA team, a framework for 
assessing  water  quality  improvement  needs  and  technical  and  institutional 
environmental  concerns  under  development  scenarios  in  selected  economic 
corridors and associated water sector plans related to the MP3EI; 
(iii)  develop policy, institutional, management and investment recommendations and 
reforms  with  the  regard  to  water  quality  improvement  and  environmental 
concerns for the CWA and each of the selected economic corridors with the 
MP3EI; develop water quality improvement plans for the economic corridors; 
(iv)  prepare relevant water quality improvement and environment sections for the 
new RPJMN along with background papers derived from the analysis for CWA; 
(v)  develop relevant sections of the ADB Indonesia water sector operational plan 
2014 to 2020; and 
(vi)  consult  with  government,  development  partners,  the  private  sector  and  civil 
society to support the TA’s water quality and environment activities. 
 
6.  Irrigation and agriculture specialist (5 person-months national). The specialist will 
(i)  collect  and  review  policy  and  regulatory  documents,  strategies,  and  other 
materials relevant to irrigation and agricultural development for the CWA; 
(ii)  prepare, in cooperation with the government and the TA team, a framework for 
assessing  needs  for  irrigation  and  agricultural  development  under  various 
scenarios in the economic corridors and associated water plans related to the 
MP3EI; 
(iii)  develop policy, institutional, management, and investment recommendations and 
reforms with regard to irrigation and agricultural development for the CWA and 
each of the economic corridors under the MP3EI; 
(iv)  prepare the sections of the RPJMN on irrigation and agricultural development, 
along with background papers derived from the analysis for the CWA; 
(v)  develop sections of the ADB water operational plan for Indonesia; and 
(vi)  consult  with  government,  development  partners,  the  private  sector,  and  civil 
society to support irrigation and agricultural activities.

Appendix 3  13 
 
7.  Water institutional specialist (4 person-months of national input).  
(i)  collect and review policies, guidelines, and regulatory frameworks from water 
institutions for the subsectors covered by the CWA; 
(ii)  highlight, based on the CWA and analysis under the MP3EI, sector performance, 
development constraints, and government policies, and recommend policy and 
institutional reforms; 
(iii)  support the team leader’s preparation of the CWA related to institutional aspects 
of the MP3EI; 
(iv)  contribute to the development of new RPJMN sections on water institutional 
issues along with background papers derived from the analysis for the CWA; 
(v)  contribute  to  the  ADB  water  operational  plan  for  Indonesia  with  regard  to 
institutional issues; and 
(vi)  consult  with  government,  development  partners,  the  private  sector,  and  civil 
society with regard to water institutional issues. 
 
8.  Social poverty and gender specialists (1 person-month international and 4 person-
months national). The specialists will 
(i)  collect and review documents relevant to poverty reduction strategies and social 
issues, including gender aspects; 
(ii)  review the MP3EI as it relates to social issues with a particular focus on poverty 
and gender, and review and support the development of the parallel poverty 
reduction  strategy  under  the  framework  of  the  MP3EI,  which  is  ongoing  in 
BAPPENAS, and make recommendations on its implications for the water sector; 
(iii)  develop  policy,  institutional,  and  investment  recommendations  and  reforms 
affecting poverty and social issues (gender in particular) in relation to the CWA 
and the selected economic corridors under the MP3EI; 
(iv)  support the preparation of water-related sections of the new RPJMN along with 
background papers derived from the analysis for the CWA, to ensure that social 
and poverty dimensions are crosscutting priorities for water subsectors; 
(v)  support the development of the ADB water operational plan for Indonesia to 
ensure that social, gender, and poverty dimensions are included; and 
(vi)  consult with the government, development partners, the private sector, and civil 
society to support TA social, gender, and poverty dimensions. 
 
9.  Fiscal and fund flow mechanism specialist (5 person-months national). The specialist 
will 
(i)  collect  and  review  policy  and  regulatory  documents,  strategies,  and  other 
materials relevant to fiscal management, budgeting, and fund flow for the CWA; 
(ii)  prepare, in cooperation with the government and TA economists, a framework for 
assessing fiscal management, budgeting, and fund flow challenges for different 
levels of government under development scenarios in the selected economic 
corridors and associated water sector plans related to the MP3EI; 
(iii)  develop policy, institutional, management, and investment recommendations and 
reforms with regard to fiscal management, budgeting, and fund flow for the CWA; 
(iv)  support the preparation of sections of the new RPJMN, along with background 
papers  derived  from  the  analysis  for  the  CWA,  and  ensure  that  fiscal 
management, budgeting, and fund flow issues are included across all subsectors; 
(v)  provide  input  to  the  ADB  water  operational  plan  for  Indonesia  and  ADB’s 
government engagement and implementation strategies as they relate to fiscal 
management, budgeting, and fund flow; and

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
(vi)  consult with governments (local government in particular), development partners, 
the private sector, and civil society to support TA fiscal management, budgeting, 
and fund flow activities. 
 
10.  Public  consultation  facilitators  (3 positions, each 7 person-months national). The 
facilitators will 
(i)  identify, working with the government and the TA team, CWA stakeholders and 
develop a consultation plan to discuss the CWA and water sector plans for the 
selected corridors; 
(ii)  facilitate  workshops  and  conduct  dialogue  with  local  government  officials  in 
selected corridors under the MP3EI, and solicit feedback for the executing and 
implementing agencies and consultants; 
(iii)  facilitate workshops and conduct dialogue with line agency officials to discuss the 
CWA,  and  solicit  feedback  for  executing  and  implementing  agencies  and 
consultants; 
(iv)  facilitate consultation as required to prepare the new RPJMN; 
(v)  facilitate sessions and serve as rapporteurs during WLW; and  
(vi)  provide detailed minutes, summaries, and syntheses of all consultations. 
 
11.  Water Learning Week team leaders (3 person-months international and 5 person-
months national). The team leaders will 
(i)  provide leadership, coordinate outputs, ensure quality control, act as focal points 
for interaction with stakeholders, and provide overall guidance to develop and 
manage WLW; 
(ii)  identify, in consultation with the government, development partners, civil society, 
the  private  sector,  and  other  stakeholders,  key  issues  and  prepare  a WLW 
program for discussion and confirmation by the government; 
(iii)  identify needs, develop terms of reference, generate and manage contracts as 
required, and ensure quality control toward the preparation of background papers, 
proceedings,  and  other  materials  from  national  and  international  resource 
persons for the WLW; 
(iv)  prepare syntheses of key messages, reform options, action plans, and general 
proceedings for WLW; and 
(v)  supervise WLW coordinators for logistics and event management. 
 
12.  Water Learning Week coordinators (2 positions, each 4 person-months national. The 
coordinators will 
(i)  support the WLW team leader in preparing and coordinating the symposium;  
(ii)  manage all logistical aspects, including the management of attendees; and 
(iii)  perform other tasks as required for the successful delivery of the WLW. 
 
13.  Knowledge product specialists (2 person-months international and 4 person-months 
national). The specialists will 
(i)  define, in consultation with the government and ADB, themes from the CWA at 
the  least,  and  confirm  the  scope  and  contents  of  a  knowledge  product  or 
products to be developed; 
(ii)  conduct research, identify best practices, and present the Indonesian experience 
with regard to the selected knowledge product(s) for development; 
(iii)  prepare and execute a dissemination strategy for the knowledge product(s); and 
(iv)  advise  the  WLW  team  on  preparing  communication  materials  and  event 
proceedings.
